• Be prepared to categorize misbehaviors as mild/early, moderate, or severe stage • Begin to analyze if the misbehavior is due to: awareness, ability, attention-seeking, or purposeful/habitual issues

page.title:
Severe-Habitual/Long-Standing Problems When chronic misbehavior does not stem from a student’s lack of awareness or ability, and is not being exhibited because the student wants attention, then you need to assume that the behavior is now habitual/long standing and is serving some other purpose for the student.

page.title:
Early-Stage Misbehavior
Early-Stage Misbehavior
page.normal_text:
For “Early-Stage” misbehaviors, be prepared to respond with one of a variety of correction strategies that are designed to provide information.

page.title:
Menu of Early-Stage Corrections
Menu of Early-Stage Corrections
page.enlisting:
• • Gentle verbal reprimand • Discussion • • Humor • • Restitution • An emotional reaction ✓ Use planned Ignoring ✓ If behavior is severe and/or affects other students, ✓ If other students give the target student attention, ✓ Use reinforcement to encourage appropriate behavior ✓ Use frequent praise and attention ✓ Use intermittent reinforcement ✓ Ensure a 3 to 1 Ratio of positive to negative • • Gentle verbal reprimand • Discussion • • Humor • • Restitution • An emotional reaction
